Questions: What was the largest refund you ever got from a purchase?
Answers:
Twenty years ago my wife and I saw an ad in the New York Times travel section. Round trip from JFK to Barbados on the Concorde, plus a week at the hotel of your choice (there were 5 hotels to choose from).

The Concorde? Let’s do it.

We called British Airways Holidays. (It was still the early day of Internet commerce. Back in 2000 you picked up the landline.)

“We’re flexible on dates,” I told the agent. “But the hotel has to be the Fairmont Royal Pavilion.”

No problem. The agent found a date that worked and took our money (about $13,000 all in). Pricey, but hey — the Concorde.

Two nights before our departure date there was a message on our home answering machine. “This is British Airways Holidays. We’ve had to make some adjustments to your itinerary. You will now be staying at the Royal Pavilion’s sister property, Glitter Bay.”

Sister property. It sounds like kind of the same thing. Except it’s not. Royal Pavilion is for adults only. Glitter Bay is for families with kids. Lots and lots of kids. We love kids. We raised two. But the reason we picked the Royal Pavilion was because we wanted to spend a week without kids.

I called British Airways Holidays. No answer. They’re not an airline. They’re just the travel planners for the airline and work from 9 to 5. We left a voicemail.

The next morning we called the Royal Pavilion and spoke to the General Manager of both properties. He said, “British Airways does this all the time. They take your money, and then they switch your hotel. Here’s what I can do. For the same price I can put you up in a large one-bedroom private villa at Glitter Bay. It’s off the beaten path, far from the kids, an easy walk to the Royal Pavilion, and you’ll have complete access to all our facilities and amenities. I’ll send my wife over to take photos of the villa.”

An hour later I got the pictures. It was incredible. We decided to take it.

British Airways never called back. The guest relations guy who met us at the airport in Barbados never told us we’d been switched to another hotel. He drove us to Glitter Bay. Or as we called it all week, Glitter Bait and Switch.

Let me sum up that week-long vacation: The Concorde was a once in a lifetime experience. Our villa was spectacular. But still, it wasn’t what we’d signed on for.

The General Manager was a total sweetheart. He suggested that I write to British Airways, but warned me not to get my hopes up for a refund.

We’ll just see about that decided the man who writes for a living. I spent days crafting the letter. A week after I sent it I got a call from a British Airways rep in London. She apologized for the “misunderstanding,” and asked how she could make it right.

I told her I wanted a public apology. An ad in the New York Times travel section telling the world what they had done and promising not to sucker in any more people. She said, “Sir, we can’t do that.”

I told her if she didn’t I would go public on this Internet thing that was still just taking hold and tell the whole world wide web what a bunch of crooks they were.

She said, “I’ll get back to you.”

A week later she called back. “We’d like to offer you and your wife an all-expense paid trip from New York to London,” she said. “We’ll fly you there on the Concorde, put you up in a five-star hotel, and fly you back first class on a 747.”

If she had seen the look on my face, she’d have known she had me. But she couldn’t see me. So I doubled down.

“Absolutely not,” I said. “You already flew me to a hotel I didn’t want to go to. Why would I want you to fly me to another place I don’t want to go to? I want a public apology. An ad in the New York Times.”

“Let me talk to my management,” she said.

Another week passed. She called back. “Sir, we absolutely can’t print a public apology. The best we can offer you is a full refund. Airfare and your entire hotel bill including meals and other amenities and services you may have charged. If you say yes, we will credit your American Express card with the entire amount.”

I grumbled, and told her that it wasn’t what I wanted, but she’d won. I begrudgingly accepted the more than $13,000 refund.

Then I hung up, did a happy dance, and told my wife the news.

The next day I called the General Manager of the Royal Pavilion and booked their best villa for a week the following spring. Three bedrooms. Perfect for me, my wife, my son, my daughter and their significant others. The cost of the villa, along with airfare (non-supersonic) for six people — a little over $13,000.

Best all-expenses-paid vacation ever.

—————————————————————

I’d have thought that after 20 years it would be lost to the ages, but I was amazed to see that it was still buried in my archives. It’s 1700 words, and I’d be embarrassed to reprint it. My recounting of the event on Quora was written with a smile on my face. The complaint letter is me at my pissiest.

But I can give you the highlights. Basically, the letter stated the facts. Re-reading it after 20 years, it’s clear that British Airways was even more underhanded than I remembered, so those facts were pretty damning. The manager of the Royal Pavilion taught me some of the tricks of the trade, and he explained why they waited till I was 48 hours away from departure, even though they knew they had overbooked weeks before. He also assured me that BA overbooked, not the hotel. I made sure they knew I was a very knowledgeable consumer.

My closing was this: “I feel violated and am angry enough to take my complaint to the FAA, the appropriate consumer fraud departments in New York, the travel press and travel newsgroups on the Internet. I also feel justified in pursuing legal action where I would seek compensation for both the cost of a lost vacation and for being the victim of dishonest business practices.”

But my best line was this: “Under no condition would I have considered a vacation at Glitter Bay, much less pay $13,186.90 for the privilege of living in the middle of a high rent day care center.”

It’s hard to go up against a corporate Goliath and win. But every now and then… I hope this is the kind of encouragement you need to never quit trying.

Questions: How can you learn faster?
Answers:
Here are 10 (literally) battle-tested ways that you can learn anything faster. I used these strategies to become a BJJ world champion a few years ago, a top writer on Medium, and to improve my relationships and mental health.

1. Ridiculously specific goals.

Goal-setting is everything, and most people do it wrong. “I want to be a champion” isn’t a goal, it’s a dream. Try, “I want to improve a ____ aspect of ____ skill today”. Specific goals will change your life.

2. Shock your environment.

Skill development comes at the intersection of the comfort zone and your limitations. By shocking your environment thoughtfully, you can simultaneously improve your skills without completely shattering your comfort zone.

3. Practice in public.

For martial arts, this means competing. For writing, this means publishing. Practicing in public is the ultimate way to test your skills and get a better idea of where you’re really at.

4. Quit.

Don’t quit the thing you’re trying to improve at, quit everything else that is of no use to you and your skill development. Quit bad relationships, quit draining jobs, and quit your bad habits. Quit things that drain your energy.

5. Teach other people.

When I started teaching, I didn’t get paid for it. However, the benefits I received from my early teaching was that I learned how I learn. Learning to teach helped me teach myself how to learn better.

6. Rest.

Burnout is very real, and it’s where skill development goes to die. Relax. Take a break. Take a mental vacation every once in a while. The grind will always be there. If you never take time to chill, you’ll struggle to keep up with the pace of improvement.

7. Read and write about your skill.

Writing is organized thought. Reading is the study of someone else’s organized thought. The more you study, the more you can absorb. Just remember to rest your mind too every now and again.

8. Study yourself.

Self-awareness is a bit of a doozy for some people, but if you want to get better faster, it’s a requirement. You need to know where you are in order to get better faster.

9. Micro-drilling.

I’ve been using micro-drilling to improve my BJJ technique and headline writing for a year now, and it’s changed my life. Micro-drilling is the isolated repetition and “drilling” of a specific technique or concept within a larger domain. This is the “grind” of skill development. Periodic grinding is good for you.

10. Enjoy yourself (like, for real).

At the end of the day, all of the learning we do doesn’t change the fact that our time on this earth is limited. If you struggle with the concept of your own mortality and your own limitations, you’ll also struggle with the abundance mindset that can help propel you in skill development. This sounds corny, but it’s true: the memories you make are just as important as the stuff you learn.

“If you know the way broadly you will see it in everything.”― Miyamoto Musashi

Questions: I sent some money to an online romance scammer. How can I get my money back?
Answers:
Everyone wants to find love, right? About a million people around the world use social networks and online dating apps to find someone. But many people, instead of meeting the love of their lives, stumble upon online scammers who try to trick them into sending them money.

These online romance scammers create fake accounts on online dating apps and websites or directly reach their target audience through popular social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram , Snapchat, Google Hangout, etc. After gaining trust, they set up fake accounts. stories to gain sympathy and ask for money. What is a romance scam?

When a person is led to believe that they are in a romantic relationship with someone they met online when in reality, their significant other is a cybercriminal using a fake identity to curry favor with them and make demands they send money or blackmail her, this is called online love scam.

**Common forms of romance scams**

Often, scammers do not provide accurate information about themselves and pretend that they are in a profession or in a more difficult place to meet. Some reasons are mentioned below:

* They were recruited as military personnel or soldiers.

* They work as doctors or medical staff abroad for charity. * They reside in any other foreign country.

* They trade internationally.

* These are businessmen or women working abroad.

* They work on an oil rig abroad.

These scammers often make up false stories so that victims can easily trust them and receive love and financial help from them, such as:

* They are seriously ill and need money for surgery or other medical expenses. * They conduct business and have an opportunity for you to invest.

* They are stuck abroad or their visa has expired and they need money for visa, airfare or other travel expenses.

* They have debts to pay and need money to pay them.

* They need cash to import and export products as well as pay customs fees.

In such cases, scammers often ask to make a bank transfer. Ask you to buy gift cards from sites like Amazon, iTunes, Google Play, and Google Cards, and send images of the gift card codes so you can use them to buy things later. The goal is that they can receive money quickly and above all anonymously.

**How ​​do I report an online dating scam?**

Have you ever thought you were being scammed online? Have you ever sent money to someone you connected with online to help them overcome a financial difference? Or is someone offering you the opportunity to invest in their business or online business? If you answered yes to any of the above questions or sent money to someone you've never met in person, you may be the target of a romance scam.

Victims of online romance scams should seek help from recovery companies like trustsiege, which will increase their chances of recovering their lost money.

Questions: Have you ever purchased a motel room only to immediately seek a refund? What was the problem?
Answers:

Questions: How can you learn faster?
Answers:
My entire educational and work career (a blend of financial mathematics) my learning was always the following;

Before (at university for example), a semester would start, I would have read the entire curriculum. Not only that, I would read far more outside of the usual curriculum. Ask others (wherever possible) who are practitioners in this field what it is they do, how it is they do things. I could be as blunt as approaching someone I knew who would work in a financial environment. I wouldn't ask, “help me, what is trading”, no, I would provide my logic and reasoning and wanted them to help show me where my thinking process was incorrect.
Before I would start a new job, I would try to reverse engineer work it is they do. I would do this by looking at their annual report. Its rather obvious that in the 300-page annual report, they showcase figures and text which they actually produce every day.

As a result, before day 1 at uni, or day 1 at work, I had a perception of something. Once I was taught by the actual professor or finance practitioner, I could compare, like for like. That is what I call learning. Fast learning. Proper learning.

And I felt, a result, I progressed quicker than my peers.

I wouldn't ask a professor how to derive black and scholes. I would ask him if my way would be acceptable, and I would also apply this from a practitioner point of view. Deriving radon-nikodym, vasicek, or b&s means nothing. Usefulness and weaknesses in a practitioner format means everything

I could literally read up on a whole year of history books before my semester started in high school. Or having read, practiced everything in a module, before day 1 of the semester at uni started. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out what you might get taught at year 3 during your first weeks as a first year BSc student.

F# focus, f# schedules and lists and reminders. It (in my opinion) gives a false sense of control or knowing what you are doing.

Nothing prevents you, if a financial career is what you are looking for to start trading now, start reading now, and not let your life be driven by others or mentors or whatever. Practice what you read.

An example, bonds, interest rate and stock prices.

You read about a relationship. Don't take it for a blind fact.

F# that.

Download the data, do the regressions, think out loud what it is you do, and report your observations to your professor. That is how you learn.

Questions: If a meal takes an excessively long time to be served in a restaurant, is it acceptable to tell the waiter that you no longer want it as it’s taking too long and ask for a refund?
Answers:
My husband and I took our son and his girlfriend to a new Mexican place near our local movie theater. When we got there, it was busy, but not full, and we were seated quickly.

We had prepared ahead of time by looking the menu up online and everyone knew what they wanted. We informed the server that we had a movie beginning in one hour, so we had a hard cutoff time. Then, we ordered appetizers for the table, drinks and meals.

The drinks came out, then one of the appetizers.

We nibbled on that one, and waited on the second appetizer.

30 minutes later, we still hadn’t been offered refills on our drinks when a different server buzzed by and dropped off the second appetizer.

Meanwhile, tables around us were being served, and even packing up to leave, even though they were seated after us. Something was definitely off.

I was starting to wonder if we were going to ever get our entrees. We flagged our server down, reminded him that we needed to be out in less than 30 minutes and asked him to check on our meals.

He didn’t come back for a long time, when he did, he said it would be only about 10–15 more minutes for our food. I know enough about Mexican cooking to know that meant the kitchen hadn’t even started our entrees, and wouldn’t be starting them for a while.

We told him to cancel and just bring a check for the appetizers and drinks immediately as there was no way we would have time to eat and still make it to our movie.

I felt 100% justified in that request. We made it clear up front we had a time limit. If the restaurant wasn’t going to be able to meet that, they had every opportunity to tell us before it got to that point.

The owner seemed to agree. She comped our bill that night and gave us a discount for our next visit.

ETA - just because people want to bitch.

By “drinks” I mean two waters, one iced tea and one Diet Coke.

Appetizers were chips and guacamole - filled at the server station and empanadas, which yes, have to be fried in the kitchen, that’s why we didn’t mind the guac coming out first.

Entrees were street tacos - the house specialty.

We watched tables get seated after us, have drinks and apps immediately, and get their entrees before we even got our second appetizer. There was a distinct failure on our ticket - I don’t know or CARE whose fault it was. We offered to pay for what we were served and didn’t ask for special treatment.

This wasn’t some kind of “fine dining” experience - its a restaurant that opened next door to an AMC theater with the expectation that people would often be eating before their movies.

Questions: What is the best way to tell a customer "no" to an unreasonable request for financial compensation?
Answers:
“You can start by giving me a refund of 50% of everything I’ve ever paid your company for the past six years, and then….”

It was, I don’t know, another Tuesday and I was talking to yet another customer who was being a little… let’s say over the top with the amount of a refund he felt he was entitled to for what he perceived as substandard service he had received. In my line of work at the time, as a manager of a line of business that talked to customers who were pre-selected to be likely to be angry before they even called us, much less the point where they’d demanded to talk to a manager… this wasn’t really that unusual of a shouted demand.

So how do you handle customers making unreasonable demands for financial compensation?

Don’t confront the demand directly… at least not yet.

Customers assert their right to unreasonably large financial compensation on a regular basis. That said, telling the customer they’re being unreasonable will only put you directly into conflict with the customer and that’s not a place where you want to be. Saying things like “that’s not going to happen” or “that’s unreasonable” are confrontational and does nothing to enable communication between you and the customer, much less progress towards resolution of the customer’s issue. When the customer makes an unreasonable request for financial compensation, acknowledge it but don’t confront it, we’ll get to that later.

Understand the motive.

Once you’ve acknowledge the customer’s request, you need to understand what informs that request. What’s your customer thinking? Why do they feel like you owe them that much money?

Your job right now isn’t to judge their thinking, it’s to understand their thinking. Did your product or service do damage to their property? Are they dissatisfied with the quality of service? What’s driving this feeling that they are owed substantial financial compensation?

Listen, pay attention, and don’t argue. Not yet. If you don’t understand the customer you’re just going to get into conflict with them and if you can’t empathize with their feelings on the issue then they won’t listen to you when you tell them no. Ask clarifying questions: How long have you been having problems? What were you using the product for when it failed? etc. Make sure you’ve got a really good understanding of what they’ve experienced and what they’re feeling about it.

I’ll see what I can do.

Reassure the customer that you are their advocate and you’re going to make sure that you and your company do right by them. Notice I didn’t say to reassure them that you’re going to give them the money they asked for? Don’t say that, you know the request isn’t reasonable, don’t make a promise to them that you can’t keep.

What you can and should promise the customer is that you’re going to take care of them. That you’re going to make sure their issue is addressed. That’s why you’re here after all! Customers want the reassurance that something will be done.

But what, exactly, do you do?

Strategy.

You need to put together a resolution for your customer. That may not even be financial compensation, or it may be compensation that’s less than what they’re asking for. You know what tools you have to work with to resolve issues and I highly suggest that customer service reps work with their management and management work with their senior leadership to build strategies well in advance for common complaints so that everyone involved knows what you’re able to do for a customer.

One of the biggest keys of your strategy that I see go wrong so frequently is this. If you learn nothing else here than remember this line:

Solve problems before you compensate the customer.

Questions: How can thousands of silly people sell expensive coins online when it would be so easy for the purchaser to ask for a refund and send back a fake coin?
Answers:
Virtually all valuable coins sold online nowadays are graded and “slabbed” by a numismatic grading company.

The plastic holder the coin is in is tamper-resistant: you pretty much have to destroy the holder to get the coin out.

If you took the coin out of the holder (known colloquially as a “slab”) and tried to get your money back from the seller, there isn’t a seller that I know of who would give you your money back. Taking the coin out of the “slab” invalidates any guarantee.

If you were somehow able to open the slab, remove the coin, substitute another coin of lower grade, re-seal the slab, and send it back to the seller, the seller could go back to the numismatic grading service that graded and slabbed the coin. The grading service, as part of what they do, takes pictures of coins they grade and slab. Comparison of the coin with their photos would allow the seller of the coin to determine that a substitution has been made.

There are coins that are sold online that aren’t slabbed, but they aren’t, as a rule, valuable numismatic coins. They’re either low-grade coins that are comparatively low in value, or they’re bullion “coins” where the value is in the metallic content and they are of no numismatic interest.

Also, the world of high-value numismatic buying and selling is comparatively small. I won’t say everyone knows everyone, but I will say if someone is engaged in something nefarious, word gets round pretty quickly.

However, these companies often make all the profits, leaving investors with significant losses.

**4; Signal provider fraud; **

This scam consists of companies providing signals to traders to help them make profitable trades. These companies may charge high fees for these signals but they often provide false or misleading information that can lead to financial losses.

**5; Broker fraud ;**

This scam involves companies acting as binary options brokers and taking customers' money but never making any trades. They can also create losing trades and quickly disappear with the money.

Therefore, avoid unsolicited offers or unrealistic promises of high returns and invest only with regulated and reputable brokers.
